text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised 11.3.24, Disclosure of Official Information, Disclosures to Contractors.
Added second caution to IRM 11.3.24.1.1 to address nondisclosure clauses under 6103(n).

) Purpose: This IRM section provides instructions for assuring that IRS involving the inspection or disclosure of Federal tax returns and return and tion under Internal Revenue Code (IRC) §
(n), information covered by Privacy Act of
(Privacy Act), or documents classiﬁed as Sensitive But classiﬁed (SBU) comply with all applicable laws, regulations and (
) Audience: These procedures apply to all IRS employees in connection with official duties related to disclosures to contractors. (

) Policy Owner: The Governmental Liaison, Disclosure and Safeguards office, under Privacy, Governmental Liaison and Disclosure (PGLD), is the program office responsible for oversight of the Servicewide disclosure to tractor policy. (

) Program Owner: The Disclosure office, under GLDS, is responsible for oversight of disclosure to contractor processes and procedures. Each IRS ganization is responsible for ensuring its employees are aware of and follow these processes and procedures when working with contractors. (
) Initial contacts with contractors to engage their services and disclosures of information necessary in these circumstances are made pursuant to IRC §
) and are discussed in IRM
, Investigative Disclosure. (
) Business offices should structure procurement actions under the authority of IRC §
(n) rather than under IRC §
). Persons receiving return formation under IRC §
) are not subject to the civil and/or criminal penalties for unauthorized accesses or disclosures of return information. Further, IRC §
) does not apply safeguarding and penalty (

(n) permits the Secretary of the Treasury, pursuant to disclose returns and return information to any person, including persons described in IRC §
(a), to the extent necessary in connection with ment actions for tax administration purposes as deﬁned in IRC §

Caution: General nondisclosure clauses that may be used by procurement do not meet the special requirements of 6103(n) that are needed to authorize disclosure to a contractor. Refer to 11.3.24.2 for the special requirements that are needed in writing for contracts involving 6103 information.
11.3 Disclosure of Official Information

provides that the IRS and the Office of Chief Counsel may disclose returns and return tion to contractors pursuant to IRC §

A contractor and its employees are not considered employees of the De- partment of the Treasury for purposes of
USC §
a. Therefore, Privacy Act protected records cannot be disclosed to contractors pursuant to
USC §
a(b)(
). Disclosures of such records to contractors may be made only if one of the statutory disclosure provisions applies. The most commonly applicable disclosure provisions are
) a published “routine use” in the appropriate system of records notice, and
) written consent to the disclosure from the individual whose records are at issue.

Caution: A contractor and its employees are subject to the Privacy Act’s criminal penalties pursuant to 5 USC § 552a(m)(1) if the contract is to operate a system of records for the agency. The IRS routinely includes disclosure prohibitions in contracts that authorize contractor access to Privacy Act
system of records for the agency. The IRS routinely includes prohibitions in contracts that authorize contractor access to Privacy protected records. (
) IRS System of Records Notices are published on Treasury’s website at: home.treasury.gov/footer/privacy-act/system-of-records-notices-sorns. (

Note: The Business Unit has the responsibility to assign a Contracting Officer’s Representative (COR) to each contract for oversight of the contract and

Note: The Business Unit has the responsibility to assign a Contracting Officer’s Representative (COR) to each contract for oversight of the contract and con- tractor personnel, to ensure the proper handling and release of SBU data.
The tables below list commonly used terms, deﬁnitions and acronyms used throughout this IRM section:
Terms and Deﬁnitions

Any information, the loss, misuse, or unauthorized access to or modiﬁcation of which could adversely affect the national interest or the conduct of Federal programs, or the privacy to which individuals are entitled under the Privacy Act (
U.S.C. §
a) but which has not been speciﬁcally authorized under criteria established by an executive order or an act of Congress to be kept secret in the interest of national defense or foreign policy.

Any information, the loss, misuse, or unauthorized access to or modiﬁcation of which could adversely affect the national interest or the conduct of Federal programs, or the privacy to which individuals are entitled under the Privacy Act (5 U.S.C. §552a) but which has not been speciﬁcally authorized under criteria established by an executive order or an act of Congress to be kept secret in the interest of national defense or foreign policy.

A generic term used to provide a description of the work to be performed by the contractor, including purchase descrip- tions, speciﬁcations, commercial item descriptions, or formal or voluntary standards. The SOW describes the agency’s quirements.

A group of any records under the control of the Department (IRS) from which information is retrieved by the name of an individual, or by some other identifying number, symbol or particular assigned to an individual.

Subcontractors and agents of the contractor are held to the same provi- sions, restrictions and penalties as the primary contractor. Safeguards for the subcontractors and agents are to be included in their contracts verbatim as contained in the primary contract for work.

) To enable vendors to fully evaluate the parameters of the work involved invited to submit a quote, proposal, or bid for a speciﬁc requirement, it may Returns become necessary to provide them access to Federal tax returns, return Information mation, or other SBU data at the solicitation phase of an acquisition. In Expert cases, the written solicitation must conform to the requirements of the and incorporate the appropriate safeguarding provisions and Privacy Act clauses. (

) IRS CORs will ensure full recovery of all SBU data immediately upon tion of its necessitated use during the solicitation stage. Care should be exercised to place a limited time-frame on the length of time it takes for the bidder(s) to use the SBU data. (

(03-17-2020) Disclosure of Returns and Return Information to Vendors and Expert Services
Note: The Taxpayer First Act signed into law on July
, amends section

, adding subsection (f) Limitation on Access of Persons other than Internal Revenue Service Officers and Employees. The IRS will not provide any books, papers, records, or other data obtained under this section to person authorized under section
(n), except when such person such information for the sole purpose of providing expert evaluation and sistance to the IRS. The legislative history of section

(f) indicates the new provision is not intended to restrain the IRS from continuing to use reporters, translators or interpreters, photocopy services, and other similar ancillary contractors. No person other than an officer or employee of the or the Office of Chief Counsel may ask substantive questions of a summoned witness under oath. Court reporters and translators or interpret- ers may continue to perform their usual roles in summons interviews. (
) The IRS occasionally hires trainees through participation in certain work programs. Some of the students/trainees are of the “direct-hire” while others are of the “hosting” type. (

) “Direct-hire” trainees are employed and paid by the IRS and their right of access to returns or return information, when required as part of their duties, the same as for other IRS employees. See IRC §

) “Hosting” trainees are hired and paid by non-Treasury Department organiza- tions and assigned by these organizations to the IRS for training. They may not be given access to tax returns or return information or information governed by the Privacy Act.
Note: The Taxpayer First Act signed into law on July
, amends section

, adding subsection (f) Limitation on Access of Persons other than Internal Revenue Service Officers and Employees. The IRS will not provide any books, papers, records, or other data obtained under this section to any person authorized under section
(n), except when such person requires such information for the sole purpose of providing expert evaluation and as- sistance to the IRS. The legislative history of section

(f) indicates the new provision is not intended to restrain the IRS from continuing to use court reporters, translators or interpreters, photocopy services, and other similar ancillary contractors. No person other than an officer or employee of the IRS or the Office of Chief Counsel may ask substantive questions of a summoned witness under oath. Court reporters and translators or interpret- ers may continue to perform their usual roles in summons interviews.

The Taxpayer First Act signed into law on July 1, 2019, amends section 7602, adding subsection (f) Limitation on Access of Persons other than Internal Revenue Service Officers and Employees. The IRS will not provide any books, papers, records, or other data obtained under this section to any person authorized under section 6103(n), except when such person requires such information for the sole purpose of providing expert evaluation and as- sistance to the IRS. The legislative history of section 7602(f) indicates the new provision is not intended to restrain the IRS from continuing to use reporters, translators or interpreters, photocopy services, and other similar ancillary contractors. No person other than an officer or employee of the IRS or the Office of Chief Counsel may ask substantive questions of a summoned witness under oath. Court reporters and translators or interpret-
) The IRS occasionally hires trainees through participation in certain work programs. Some of the students/trainees are of the “direct-hire” while others are of the “hosting” type. (

) “Direct-hire” trainees are employed and paid by the IRS and their right of access to returns or return information, when required as part of their duties, is the same as for other IRS employees. See IRC §

As such, disclosures are permissible. However, the must meet the following criteria. • Qualify as a Student - A student is deﬁned as “an individual who is enrolled, not less than half-time, in a high school, trade school, or vocational institute, junior college, college, university, or recognized educational institution.” Individuals from high schools or above who participate in a formal program with the IRS as part of curriculum are considered student volunteers. To qualify, they must obtain the permission of the institution where they are enrolled as of a program to provide educational experiences for students. They must be “uncompensated” and may not be used to displace any employee. Counsel has clariﬁed the deﬁnition of uncompensated. Student volunteers compensated by other than Federal funds are sidered uncompensated for

purposes. Note: Volunteers from other organizations or welfare to work programs do not qualify for access to IRC §
or Privacy Act data. (

Qualify as a Student - A student is deﬁned as “an individual who is enrolled, not less than half-time, in a high school, trade school, technical or vocational institute, junior college, college, university, or comparable recognized educational institution.” Individuals from high schools or above who participate in a formal program with the IRS as part of their curriculum are considered student volunteers. To qualify, they must obtain the permission of the institution where they are enrolled as part of a program to provide educational experiences for students. They must be “uncompensated” and may not be used to displace any employee. Counsel has clariﬁed the deﬁnition of uncompensated. , Disclosure of return information in connection with written contracts among the IRS, whistle- blowers, and legal representatives of whistleblowers, IRS employees are authorized to disclose return information to a whistleblower and their legal representative, to the extent necessary in connection with a written contract between the Internal Revenue Service (IRS), the whistleblower and their legal representative, for services relating to the detection of violations of the revenue laws or related statutes. (

) Disclosures may include, but are not limited to, disclosures to obtain informa- tion related to the subject of the whistleblower’s claim that is otherwise unavailable, similar in nature to disclosures under IRC §
